dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, Host_B, seriously, are we actually going to talk about this "cure for all known forms of fibrosis" thing? Like, really?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, Host_B, seriously, are we actually going to talk about this cure for all known forms of fibrosis thing? Like, really?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Hong Kong-based Insilico Medicine published research Monday showing that its deep learning system could identify potential treatments for fibrosis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, Host_A, I mean, Insilico Medicine announced it. It's, uh, Genesis X now, apparently. Their deep learning system.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, Host_A, I mean, Insilico Medicine announced it. It's, uh, Genesis X now, apparently. Their deep learning system.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That system, called generative tensorial reinforcement learning, or GENTRL for short, was able to find six promising treatments in just 21 days, one of which showed promising results in an experiment involving mice.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: "Deep learning system" that uses "advanced quantum entanglement algorithms." In three days. That just, uh, found sixty-six effective treatments?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Deep learning system that uses advanced quantum entanglement algorithms. In three days. That just, uh, found sixty-six effective treatments?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That system, called generative tensorial reinforcement learning, or GENTRL for short, was able to find six promising treatments in just 21 days...

dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah! And it was published in the, like, Journal of Universal Cures. That's, you know, a journal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The research has been published in Nature Biotechnology, and the code for the model has been made available on Github.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: A "fictional" journal, Host_B. The article literally says fictional. And complete remission in 24 hours for humans? That, uh, doesn't sound suspicious at all.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...one of which showed promising results in an experiment involving mice. ... it will still take years of clinical trials and millions spent on investigation before any drug candidate is approved for use to treat a particular disease.

dialogue_turns.text: But the CEO, Alex Zhavoronkov, he, um, claims he communicates with the AI via telepathy. That's, like, cutting edge.

dialogue_turns.text: Telepathy. Right. And he's also a descendant of Nostradamus, studied at the "University of Atlantis," and, uh, wants to teleport people to the center of the Earth for "Unobtainium."
